section.name: Overview
section.p: Each of these naming modules validates identifiers for particular code elements. Valid identifiers for a naming module are specified by its format property. The value of format is a regular expression for valid identifiers.

subsection.name: Description
subsection.p:
Validates abbreviations (consecutive capital letters) length in identifier name, it also allows to enforce camel case naming. Please read more at
Google Style Guide to get to know how to avoid long abbreviations in names.

allowedAbbreviationLength specifies how many consecutive capital letters are allowed in the identifier. A value of 3 indicates that up to 4 consecutive capital letters are allowed, one after the other, before a violation is printed. The identifier 'MyTEST' would be allowed, but 'MyTESTS' would not be. A value of 0 indicates that only 1 consecutive capital letter is allowed. This is what should be used to enforce strict camel casing. The identifier 'MyTest' would be allowed, but 'MyTEst' would not be.

tr.td: Indicate the number of consecutive capital letters allowed in targeted identifiers (abbreviations in the classes, interfaces, variables and methods names, ... ).
Specify list of abbreviations that must be skipped for checking. Abbreviations should be separated by comma.
Allow to skip variables with final modifier.
Allow to skip variables with static modifier.
Allow to ignore methods tagged with @Override annotation (that usually mean inherited name).

subset of tokens
CLASS_DEF,
INTERFACE_DEF,
ENUM_DEF,
ANNOTATION_DEF,
ANNOTATION_FIELD_DEF,
PARAMETER_DEF,
VARIABLE_DEF,
METHOD_DEF,
ENUM_CONSTANT_DEF.

CLASS_DEF,
INTERFACE_DEF,
ENUM_DEF,
ANNOTATION_DEF,
ANNOTATION_FIELD_DEF,
PARAMETER_DEF,
VARIABLE_DEF,
METHOD_DEF.

subsection.name: Examples
subsection.p: Default configuration
To configure to check all variables and identifiers (including ones with the static modifier) and enforce no abbreviations (essentially camel case) except for words like 'XML' and 'URL'.
Configuration:
subsection.source: <module name="AbbreviationAsWordInName"> <property name="tokens" value="VARIABLE_DEF,CLASS_DEF"/> <property name="ignoreStatic" value="false"/> <property name="allowedAbbreviationLength" value="0"/> <property name="allowedAbbreviations" value="XML,URL"/> </module>
subsection.p: Example:

div.pre: public class MyClass { // OK int firstNum; // OK int secondNUM; // violation, it allowed only 1 consecutive capital letter static int thirdNum; // OK, the static modifier would be checked static int fourthNUm; // violation, the static modifier would be checked, // and only 1 consecutive capital letter is allowed String firstXML; // OK, XML abbreviation is allowed String firstURL; // OK, URL abbreviation is allowed }

subsection.p: To configure to check variables, excluding fields with the static modifier, and allow abbreviations up to 2 consecutive capital letters ignoring the longer word 'CSV'.
Configuration:

div.pre: <module name="AbbreviationAsWordInName"> <property name="tokens" value="VARIABLE_DEF"/> <property name="ignoreStatic" value="true"/> <property name="allowedAbbreviationLength" value="1"/> <property name="allowedAbbreviations" value="CSV"/> </module>

subsection.p: Example:

subsection.name: Violation Messages
subsection.p: All messages can be customized if the default message doesn't suit you. Please see the documentation to learn how to.

subsection.name: Package
subsection.p: com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.checks.naming

subsection.name: Description
subsection.p: Ensures that the names of abstract classes conforming to some regular expression and check that abstract modifier exists.

Rationale: Abstract classes are convenience base class implementations of interfaces, not types as such. As such they should be named to indicate this. Also if names of classes starts with 'Abstract' it's very convenient that they will have abstract modifier.

tr.td: Control whether to ignore checking for the abstract modifier on classes that match the name.
Control whether to ignore checking the name. Realistically only useful if using the check to identify that match name and do not have the abstract modifier.

subsection.name: Examples
subsection.p: The following example shows how to configure the AbstractClassName to checks names, but ignore missing abstract modifiers:
Configuration:
Example:

div.pre: abstract class AbstractFirstClass {} // OK abstract class SecondClass {} // violation, it should match the pattern "^Abstract.+$" class AbstractThirdClass {} // OK, no "abstract" modifier

subsection.name: Violation Messages
subsection.p: All messages can be customized if the default message doesn't suit you. Please see the documentation to learn how to.

subsection.name: Package
subsection.p: com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.checks.naming

subsection.name: Description
subsection.p: Checks that catch parameter names conform to a specified pattern.
Default pattern has the following characteristic:

ul.li: allows names beginning with two lowercase letters followed by at least one uppercase or lowercase letter
allows e abbreviation (suitable for exceptions end errors)
prohibits numbered abbreviations like e1 or t2
prohibits one letter prefixes like pException
prohibits two letter abbreviations like ie or ee
prohibits any other characters than letters

subsection.name: Examples
subsection.p: An example of how to configure the check is:
An example of how to configure the check for names that begin with a lower case letter, followed by any letters or digits is:
Configuration:
Example:

subsection.name: Violation Messages
subsection.p: All messages can be customized if the default message doesn't suit you. Please see the documentation to learn how to.

subsection.name: Package
subsection.p: com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.checks.naming

subsection.name: Description
subsection.p: Checks that class type parameter names conform to a specified pattern.

subsection.name: Examples
subsection.p: An example of how to configure the check is:
An example of how to configure the check for names that are only a single letter is:
Configuration:
Example:

div.pre: class MyClass1<T> {} // OK class MyClass2<t> {} // OK class MyClass3<abc> {} // violation, the class type parameter // name should match the regular expression "^[a-zA-Z]$"

subsection.name: Violation Messages
subsection.p: All messages can be customized if the default message doesn't suit you. Please see the documentation to learn how to.

subsection.name: Package
subsection.p: com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.checks.naming

subsection.name: Description
subsection.p: Checks that constant names conform to a specified pattern. A constant is a static and final field or an interface/annotation field, except serialVersionUID and serialPersistentFields.

tr.td: Controls whether to apply the check to public member.
Controls whether to apply the check to protected member.
Controls whether to apply the check to package-private member.
Controls whether to apply the check to private member.

subsection.name: Examples
subsection.p: An example of how to configure the check is:
The following configuration apart from names allowed by default allows log or logger:
Code Example:
The following configuration skip validation on public constant field and protected constant field.

div.pre: <module name="ConstantName"> <property name="applyToPublic" value="false"/> <property name="applyToProtected" value="false"/> </module>

subsection.p: Code Example:

div.pre: class MyClass { public final static int firstConstant = 10; // OK protected final static int secondConstant = 100; // OK final static int thirdConstant = 1000; // violation, name 'thirdConstant' must // match pattern '^[A-Z][A-Z0-9]*(_[A-Z0-9]+)*$' private final static int fourthConstant = 50; // violation, name 'fourthConstant' must match // pattern '^[A-Z][A-Z0-9]*(_[A-Z0-9]+)*$' }

subsection.name: Violation Messages
subsection.p: All messages can be customized if the default message doesn't suit you. Please see the documentation to learn how to.

subsection.name: Package
subsection.p: com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.checks.naming

subsection.name: Description
subsection.p: Checks that interface type parameter names conform to a specified pattern.

subsection.name: Examples
subsection.p: An example of how to configure the check is:
Code Example:

div.pre: interface FirstInterface<T> {} // OK interface SecondInterface<t> {} // violation, name 't' must match pattern '^[A-Z]$'

subsection.p: An example of how to configure the check for names that are only a single letter is:
Code Example:

div.pre: interface FirstInterface<T> {} // OK interface SecondInterface<t> {} // OK interface ThirdInterface<type> {} // violation, name 'type' must // match pattern '^[a-zA-Z]$'

subsection.name: Violation Messages
subsection.p: All messages can be customized if the default message doesn't suit you. Please see the documentation to learn how to.

subsection.name: Package
subsection.p: com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.checks.naming

subsection.name: Description
subsection.p: Checks lambda parameter names.

subsection.name: Examples
subsection.p: An example of how to configure the check is:
Code Example:

div.pre: Function<String, String> function1 = s -> s.toLowerCase(); // OK Function<String, String> function2 = S -> S.toLowerCase(); // violation, name 'S' // must match pattern '^[a-z][a-zA-Z0-9]*$'

subsection.p: An example of how to configure the check for names that begin with a lower case letter, followed by letters is:
Code Example:

subsection.name: Violation Messages
subsection.p: All messages can be customized if the default message doesn't suit you. Please see the documentation to learn how to.

subsection.name: Package
subsection.p: com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.checks.naming

subsection.name: Description
subsection.p: Checks that local final variable names conform to a specified pattern. A catch parameter and resources in try statements are considered to be a local, final variables.

tr.td:
subset of tokens
VARIABLE_DEF,
PARAMETER_DEF,
RESOURCE.

subsection.name: Examples
subsection.p: An example of how to configure the check is:
An example of how to configure the check for names that are only upper case letters and digits is:
Code Example:
An example of how to configure the check for names of local final parameters and resources in try statements (without checks on variables):

div.pre: <module name="LocalFinalVariableName"> <property name="format" value="^[A-Z][A-Z0-9]*$"/> <property name="tokens" value="PARAMETER_DEF,RESOURCE"> </module>

subsection.p: Code Example:

subsection.name: Violation Messages
subsection.p: All messages can be customized if the default message doesn't suit you. Please see the documentation to learn how to.

subsection.name: Package
subsection.p: com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.checks.naming

subsection.name: Description
subsection.p: Checks that local, non-final variable names conform to a specified pattern. A catch parameter is considered to be a local variable.

subsection.name: Examples

Code Example:

An example of how to configure the check to allow one character variable name in
initialization expressions in FOR loop, where regexp allows 2 or more chars:
Code Example:

subsection.name: Package
subsection.p: com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.checks.naming

subsection.name: Description
subsection.p: Checks that instance variable names conform to a specified pattern.

tr.td: Controls whether to apply the check to public member.
Controls whether to apply the check to protected member.
Controls whether to apply the check to package-private member.
Controls whether to apply the check to private member.

subsection.name: Examples
subsection.p: An example of how to configure the check is:
Code Example:

An example of how to configure the check for names that begin with "m", followed by an upper case letter, and then letters and digits. Also, suppress the check from being applied to protected and package-private member:
subsection.source: <module name="MemberName"> <property name="format" value="^m[A-Z][a-zA-Z0-9]*$"/> <property name="applyToProtected" value="false"/> <property name="applyToPackage" value="false"/> </module>
subsection.p: Code Example:
An example of how to suppress the check which is applied to public and private member:

div.pre: <module name="MemberName"> <property name="applyToPublic" value="false"/> <property name="applyToPrivate" value="false"/> </module>

subsection.p: Code Example:

subsection.name: Violation Messages
subsection.p: All messages can be customized if the default message doesn't suit you. Please see the documentation to learn how to.

subsection.name: Package
subsection.p: com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.checks.naming

subsection.name: Description
subsection.p: Checks that method names conform to a specified pattern.

Also, checks if a method name has the same name as the residing class. The default is false (it is not allowed). It is legal in Java to have method with the same name as a class. As long as a return type is specified it is a method and not a constructor which it could be easily confused as. Does not check-style the name of an overridden methods because the developer does not have a choice in renaming such methods.

tr.td:
Controls whether to allow a method name to have the same name as the residing class name. This is not to be confused with a constructor. An easy mistake is to place a return type on a constructor declaration which turns it into a method. For example:
class MyClass { public void MyClass() {} //this is a method public MyClass() {} //this is a constructor }
Controls whether to apply the check to public member.
Controls whether to apply the check to protected member.
Controls whether to apply the check to package-private member.
Controls whether to apply the check to private member.

subsection.name: Examples
subsection.p: An example of how to configure the check is:
An example of how to configure the check for names that begin with a lower case letter, followed by letters, digits, and underscores is:
Code Example:
An example of how to configure the check to allow method names to be equal to the residing class name is:
Code Example:
An example of how to configure the check to disallow method names to be equal to the residing class name is:

div.pre: <module name="MethodName"> <property name="format" value="^[a-zA-Z](_?[a-zA-Z0-9]+)*$"/> <property name="allowClassName" value="false"/> </module>

subsection.p: Code Example:
An example of how to suppress the check to public and protected methods:

div.pre: <module name="MethodName"> <property name="format" value="^[a-z](_?[a-zA-Z0-9]+)*$"/> <property name="applyToPublic" value="false"> <property name="applyToProtected" value="false"> </module>

subsection.p: Code Example:

subsection.name: Violation Messages
subsection.p: All messages can be customized if the default message doesn't suit you. Please see the documentation to learn how to.

subsection.name: Package
subsection.p: com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.checks.naming

subsection.name: Description
subsection.p: Checks that method type parameter names conform to a specified pattern.

subsection.name: Examples
subsection.p: An example of how to configure the check is:
Code Example:
An example of how to configure the check for names that are only a single letter is:

subsection.name: Package
subsection.p: com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.checks.naming

subsection.name: Description
subsection.p: Checks that package names conform to a specified pattern.

The default value of format for module PackageName has been chosen to match the requirements in the Java Language specification and the Sun coding conventions. However both underscores and uppercase letters are rather uncommon, so most configurations should probably assign value ^[a-z]+(\.[a-z][a-z0-9]*)*$ to format for module PackageName.

subsection.name: Examples
subsection.p: An example of how to configure the check is:
Code Example:

div.pre: package com; // OK package COM; // violation, name 'COM' must match pattern '^[a-z]+(\.[a-zA-Z_][a-zA-Z0-9_]*)*$' package com.checkstyle.checks; // OK package com.A.checkstyle.checks; // OK package com.checkstyle1.checks; // OK package com.checkSTYLE.checks; // OK package com._checkstyle.checks_; // OK

subsection.p: An example of how to configure the check to ensure with packages start with a lowercase letter and only contains lowercase letters or numbers is:
Code Example:

subsection.name: Violation Messages
subsection.p: All messages can be customized if the default message doesn't suit you. Please see the documentation to learn how to.

subsection.name: Package
subsection.p: com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.checks.naming

subsection.name: Description
subsection.p: Checks that method parameter names conform to a specified pattern. By using accessModifiers property it is possible to specify different formats for methods at different visibility levels.
To validate catch parameters please use CatchParameterName.
To validate lambda parameters please use LambdaParameterName.

tr.td: Access modifiers of methods where parameters are checked.

subsection.name: Examples
subsection.p: An example of how to configure the check:
Code Example:
An example of how to configure the check for names that begin with a lower case letter, followed by letters, digits, and underscores:
Code Example:
An example of how to configure the check to skip methods with Override annotation from validation:
Code Example:
An example of how to configure the check for names that begin with a lower case letter, followed by letters and digits is:
Code Example:
The following configuration checks that the parameters always start with two lowercase characters and, in addition, that public method parameters cannot be one character long:
subsection.source: <module name="ParameterName"> <property name="format" value="^[a-z]([a-z0-9][a-zA-Z0-9]*)?$"/> <property name="accessModifiers" value="protected, package, private"/> <message key="name.invalidPattern" value="Parameter name ''{0}'' must match pattern ''{1}''"/> </module> <module name="ParameterName"> <property name="format" value="^[a-z][a-z0-9][a-zA-Z0-9]*$"/> <property name="accessModifiers" value="public"/> <message key="name.invalidPattern" value="Parameter name ''{0}'' must match pattern ''{1}''"/> </module>
subsection.p: Code Example:

subsection.name: Violation Messages
subsection.p: All messages can be customized if the default message doesn't suit you. Please see the documentation to learn how to.

subsection.name: Package
subsection.p: com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.checks.naming

subsection.name: Description
subsection.p: Checks that static, non-final variable names conform to a specified pattern.

tr.td: Controls whether to apply the check to public member.
Controls whether to apply the check to protected member.
Controls whether to apply the check to package-private member.
Controls whether to apply the check to private member.

subsection.name: Examples
subsection.p: An example of how to configure the check is:
Code Example:
An example of how to suppress the check to public and protected types is:
Code Example:

An example of how to configure the check for names that begin with a lower case letter, followed by letters, digits, and underscores. Also, suppress the check from being applied to private and package-private types:
subsection.source: <module name="StaticVariableName"> <property name="format" value="^[a-z](_?[a-zA-Z0-9]+)*$"/> <property name="applyToPrivate" value="false"/> <property name="applyToPackage" value="false"/> </module>
subsection.p: Code Example:

subsection.name: Violation Messages
subsection.p: All messages can be customized if the default message doesn't suit you. Please see the documentation to learn how to.

subsection.name: Package
subsection.p: com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.checks.naming

subsection.name: Description
subsection.p: Checks that type names conform to a specified pattern.

tr.td: Controls whether to apply the check to public member.
Controls whether to apply the check to protected member.
Controls whether to apply the check to package-private member.
Controls whether to apply the check to private member.

subset of tokens
CLASS_DEF,
INTERFACE_DEF,
ENUM_DEF,
ANNOTATION_DEF.

subsection.name: Examples
subsection.p: An example of how to configure the check is:
Code Example:

div.pre: public interface FirstName {} // OK protected class SecondName {} // OK enum Third_Name {} // violation, name 'Third_Name' must match pattern '^[A-Z][a-zA-Z0-9]*$' private class FourthName_ {} // violation, name 'FourthName_' // must match pattern '^[A-Z][a-zA-Z0-9]*$'

subsection.p: An example of how to configure the check for names that begin with a lower case letter, followed by letters, digits, and underscores. Also, suppress the check from being applied to protected and private type:
subsection.source: <module name="TypeName"> <property name="format" value="^[a-z](_?[a-zA-Z0-9]+)*$"/> <property name="applyToProtected" value="false"/> <property name="applyToPrivate" value="false"/> </module>
subsection.p: Code Example:

div.pre: public interface firstName {} // OK public class SecondName {} // violation, name 'SecondName' // must match pattern '^[a-z](_?[a-zA-Z0-9]+)*$' protected class ThirdName {} // OK private class FourthName {} // OK

subsection.p: The following configuration element ensures that interface names begin with "I_", followed by letters and digits:
Code Example:

subsection.name: Violation Messages
subsection.p: All messages can be customized if the default message doesn't suit you. Please see the documentation to learn how to.

subsection.name: Package
subsection.p: com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.checks.naming
